p: Next, Laurel Bollinger’s chapter traces a number of different contagion narratives beginning with literature contemporaneous with the Spanish Influenza Epidemic to more recent science fiction. Bollinger suggests that the fear of festering microbes is a palimpsest for anxieties about gender norms; the proliferating germ inside a body turns all human bodies—that is, male and female—into gestational spaces. She goes on to show that infectious discourse is often used either to reify (what she characterizes as “epidemic narratives”) or to challenge (in the case of “endemic narratives”) normative gender constructs.
